docs.snippet: Portugal eliminated the United States yesterday, 6-5, and clinched a spot in the quarterfinals of the 16-team Beach Soccer World Cup in Rio de Janeiro.Portugal advanced from Group B; Spain was the group winner despite a 5-4 loss to Iran. The top two...
docs.lead_paragraph: Portugal eliminated the United States yesterday, 6-5, and clinched a spot in the quarterfinals of the 16-team Beach Soccer World Cup in Rio de Janeiro.Portugal advanced from Group B; Spain was the group winner despite a 5-4 loss to Iran. The top two teams in each of the four groups advance.Brazil, the defending champion, defeated Russia, 5-4, on penalties to remain unbeaten and win Group A.Mexico, a 6-3 winner over the Solomon Islands, also advanced, as did Nigeria and Senegal. Italy, Uruguay, Japan, Argentina and France are vying for the last two spots.

headline.main: U.S. Loses in Beach World Cup
headline.print_headline: U.S. Loses In Beach World Cup

docs.snippet: The Simon Wiesenthal Center is extending a campaign to search for aged Nazis to South America, where investigators say they believe Aribert Heim, left, in an undated photo, one of the most wanted suspected war criminals, is hiding. The center is...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Simon Wiesenthal Center is extending a campaign to search for aged Nazis to South America, where investigators say they believe Aribert Heim, left, in an undated photo, one of the most wanted suspected war criminals, is hiding. The center is offering a $460,000 reward for information leading to the capture of Dr. Heim, known as “Dr. Death” for allegedly performing gruesome medical experiments on concentration camp inmates. If alive, he would be 93. His daughter lives in Chile, and he continues to maintain a bank account in Germany containing more than $1 million, said Efraim Zuroff, the center’s chief Nazi hunter. Mr. Zuroff said “dozens, if not hundreds” of Nazi war criminals were hiding in South America. The countries involved in what the center calls Operation Last Chance are Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay.
